div.p: THE POOR MAN's ADVICE TO HIS POOR NEIGHBOURS: A BALLAD, To the Tune of CHEVY-CHACE.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED IN THE YEAR M.DCC.LXXIV.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: AH! have you read, my neighbours dear,
Our famous Congress Book?
Alas! I grievously do fear
They have our case mistook.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: What pity 'tis, such worthy men
Who've larnt to read, and write,
And cast accounts; should use their pen,
For to undo us quite.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: I never saw a King, or Queen,
Save Indian Kings, in Stroud,
But I've seen folks, who Kings have seen,
Who say, they're desp'rate proud.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But our King George is just and good,
If one dar'd speak out plain,
And when he's forced to shed blood,
He feels purdigious pain.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: When this book gets to London-town,
And is show'd to the King,
I will lay any man a crown,
He'll grieve, like any thing.

lg.head: VI
lg.l: To hear, such whimper, and such whine,
No man can tell him why;
And 'cause his Royal Hand must sign
That some poor souls must die.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Lord! how the Parliament men will curse
To find themselves so mawl'd;
Like soot-pad, or like vile cut-purse
They're all to nought be call'd.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: As if a pack of rascals, they
Mind not what's wrong or right,
But vote, for so much by the Day▪
As our Provincials fight.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: As who nor law, nor gospel know,
Altho' at college bred,
And as the folks in Europe trow,
In larned books deep read.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: As men, who only have a smatch
Of knowledge, for parade,
And for our Congress are no match
In politics, or trade.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: The Canagans too, whom they address,
And treat so very blunt;
Will cry, while as they cross their breasts,
Jesu! quel gros affront!

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: If to obey King George they please,
For what is all this fuss?
And love him more than Lewy Sease,
Pray what harm's that to us?

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: He graciously, their laws restor'd,
Which they had long besought;
For which, he is by them ador'd,
As every good King ought.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Oh! what sad Kings, we'd formerly
They took a wicked maggot;
To make men with their faith comply,
They used fire, and faggot.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: Now Fox's book of Marturs saith,
It is a dreadful thing,
To be oblig'd to change one's faith,
For any earthly King.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: If Algerines should take this city,
And for our faith, despise us,
'Twould be a burning shame, and pity,
If they should circumcise us.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: To the whole world, 'tis natural
To love, their ancient uses,
Of these they're full as chary all,
As we of our prepuces.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: Had Barron Descow took this town,
In fifty-sixth's hard frost,
What should we've thought, if the French crown
Had given back, all we lost.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: I've Papists known, right honest men:
Alas! what shame and pity?
Ah! how unlike the vartus Penn,
To drive them from our city.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: Of Britons, some folks tell great lies,
Us poor gulls to deceive;
And while they throw dust in our eyes,
They laff all in their sleeve.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: They love the King, and Lord North too,
And will all take their part,
For all that we can say, or do,
They will not care a f—t.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Their merchants, they think war fine fun,
For they keep out of sight;
They feel no sword, nor hear no gun,
But help pay troops to fight.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: Therefore they often, hand o'er head,
Into a war will souse,
And when news comes of thousands dead,
They mind it not a louse.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Don't you remember, t'other day
They talk'd of war with Spain;
'Bout Falkland's Island, as they say,
A vast way o'er the main.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: Lord, how did England rage and roar,
About a foolish rudder;
A war they'd have, by G-d, they swore,
And make proud Spain to shudder.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Proud Spain was soon to reason brought,
For fear of British thunder,
And though it was a bitter draught,
Yet did proud Spain knock under.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: As bitter a draught it was, 'tis true,
As I, pi, ca, cu, an, ha,
But Spain remember'd sixty-two,
As how she lost Havanna.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: Now isn't this book a much worse thing
Than that same foolish rudder;
And by affronting so their King,
Will they not make us shudder?

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: They work, for East and West-Indies,
For Russia, and for Spain;
For ev'ry land, under the skies,
And trade o'er all the main.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: Yet when the strange resolves we've made,
Are known to that proud nation,
Tho' they've enough of other trade,
Lord, what a furious passion?

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: Then for to block our port within,
Out comes their ships so stout,
And since we will let nothing in,
They will let nothing out.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: From December, the very first day,
The Delegates say plum,
Our wives shan't have a dust more tea,
Nor we a drop more rum.

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: They've tea in plenty for themselves,
And other good things too,
But we, alas, poor wretched elves,
Shall not know what to do.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: They've all laid in great stock of things,
To last them many a year,
For they're as rich as any Kings,
But what shall poor folks wear?

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: They'll ride in coach and chariot fine,
And go to ball, and play,
When we've not wherewithal to dine,
Though we work hard all day.

lg.head: XXXVI.
lg.l: Our members are good men, and true,
And plans full wise propos'd,
Their country's good for to pursue,
But East and South oppos'd.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: If New-York votes, none of th' other
Did contradict quite flat,
I do (for all this mighty pother)
Begin to smell a rat.

lg.head: XXXVIII.
lg.l: The last Non-import (lo but surch)
While Phil. and we obey'd,
The rest all left us in the lurch,
And drove a smoaking trade.

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: I fear this noise about a tax,
Is all a downright flam,
For any but a Smuggler ax,
They did not care a d—mn.

lg.head: XL.
lg.l: Ah! God forgive these wicked men,
To judge hard, I am loath;
But they don't boggle now and then,
To break a swinging oath.

lg.head: XLI.
lg.l: If all be true our Clargy say,
And what all good men tell,
Alas! at the great judgment day,
They'll all be d—d to h—ll.

lg.head: XLII.
lg.l: We know full well, that Boston town,
For many a hundred chest,
Paid three pence duty, to the Crown,
And grumbl'd not the least.

lg.head: XLIII.
lg.l: These wicked men did them persuade,
To tell a foolish lie,
And swear by G-d, that them all made,
'Twas inadvertantly.

lg.head: XLIV.
lg.l: Ah what a shame, that pious town,
Should do a thing so odd,
To turn all traitors to the Crown,
And rebels to their God.

lg.head: XLV.
lg.l: Oh would to God, they'd think betimes,
Before affairs grow worse,
And make atonement for their crimes,
By sorrow and remorse.

lg.head: XLVI.
lg.l: So may he mercifully save
That very godly city,
To lose all in the world we have,
Is surely a great pity.

lg.head: XLVII.
lg.l: And now, my Friends, lets warn'd be
By their unhappy fate,
To live in sweet tranquility
And trouble not the state.

lg.head: XLVIII.
lg.l: For if our worthy General Gage,
Whom we do all well know,
Should the New-Englanders engage,
And finally o'erthrow.

lg.head: XLIX.
lg.l: He'd greve to's heart, if order'd here
Against his old frends to fight,
He was long time, our townsman dear;
Twou'd be a dreadful sight.

lg.head: L.
lg.l: If by a maracle in war,
New-England, shou'd beat him;
They'd come by thousands, far and near,
And us most soundly trim.

lg.head: LI.
lg.l: They have already, seiz'd our land,
And Penn's too, as they say;
Now if they get, the upper hand,
Ther'll be the duce to pay.

lg.head: LII.
lg.l: Then must we feed, on salt and Sweet,
And drink, sour cyder too
If cought on sabbath, in the street,
Be flogged, black and blue.

lg.head: LIII.
lg.l: And then no living soul will dare,
To take a pleasant ride
To Kingsbridge, or Harlem so fair,
By his dear sweetheart's side.

lg.head: LIV.
lg.l: Then must we, five whole hours a stretch,
Hear their grim pastors whine,
And snuffle, and cant, and bawl, and preach,
While as we want to dine.

lg.head: LV.
lg.l: The jolly Boston sailors say,
They dare not for their lives,
If from long voyage, they land that day,
Embrace their own dear wives.

lg.head: LVI.
lg.l: With such queer folks, have nought to do
But follow, your old course,
Kiss them on mon' and sunday too,
And frolick, foot, and horse.

lg.head: LVII.
lg.l: The next time, that we want redress,
For any discontent,
Our own Assemblies, should address
The British Parliament.

lg.head: LVIII.
lg.l: I have over heard, some slyboots swear
The Congress, was a Hum,
To make old women, and children fear,
As once, at fee, fa, fum.

lg.head: LIX.
lg.l: Suppose, all truth, the Congress say,
No doubt, they make the worst;
Can we, my Friends, for many a day,
Be so completely curst.

lg.head: LX.
lg.l: As have no cloaths, no grog, no tea,
To cheer our drooping spirits;
And snug in clover, smugglers see,
Who have not half our merits.

lg.head: LXI.
lg.l: Isn't it, now a pretty story,
One smells it in a trice,
If I send wheat, I am a Tory,
But Charles-town, may sent RICE.

lg.head: LXII.
lg.l: The Congress, say, you'll all things sell
As for a twelve month past;
But don't we know, my friends, full well,
That this is all my a—e.

lg.head: LXIII.
lg.l: If we to give that price, be willing,
And go unto a store;
Instead of one, they ax two shilling,
And turn us, out of door.

lg.head: LXIV.
lg.l: Now should we raise, the price of work,
Or of our own produce,
They'd look as fierce, as any Turk,
And send us, to the duce.

lg.head: LXV.
lg.l: Indeed, indeed, it's very wicked,
For men, who an't all Fools,
To think, that we can be so tricked,
And made such harrant fools.

lg.head: LXVI.
lg.l: Oh? my dear friends, my blood does boil,
To see men, so impose,
Bend us, it will, like pliant coil;
And lead us by the nose.

lg.head: LXIVI.
lg.l: If any Lord, or Common, or King,
Had set to work, his head,
He coudn't have done, so bad a thing,
As take away, ones bread.

lg.head: LXVIII.
lg.l: Rare sons of freedom, this Congress!
So just as they think right,
We are to eat,—drink,—frolick,—dress;
Pray masters, may we s—e.

lg.head: LXIX.
lg.l: For this, they post in every city,
A pack of dreadful spies:
Did ever scheme, so mighty pretty,
Inquigishon devise?

lg.head: LXX.
lg.l: If by just wrath, the devil was sent,
To rule these fair countries,
A greater curse, he cou'dn't invent,
Than to encourage spies.

lg.head: LXXI.
lg.l: Than bid men, who should live like brothers.
To pry, both night and day,
And keep near watch, upon each other,
Each other to betray▪

lg.head: LXXII.
lg.l: Our own dear homes shall be no more
Our castles, as of old;
But grim inspectors burst our door,
And every tale be told

lg.head: LXXIII.
lg.l: In the Gazette; of what we drink,
Or eat, or buy, or sell,
Or say, or do, look, dream, or think,
Oh! what a perfect hell.

lg.head: LXXIV.
lg.l: I'd rather be a Galley Slave,
Be chained hand and foot,
Lose every precious limb I have,
Than to submit unto't.

lg.head: LXXV.
lg.l: Shades of De Witts! our souls inspire,
Their threatnings to despise;
Let's do what God, what laws require,
And laff at Congress spies.

lg.head: LXXVI.
lg.l: Monsters, stand off! avaunt! beware!
My doors ye shall not burst;
Magistrates only enter there:
Oh G-d! I'll perish first.

lg.head: LXXVII.
lg.l: Ye Good, ye Wise, ye Rich, ye Great,
These mad Resolves revurse,
Stand forth! Oh quit your mean retreat;
Remember Meroth's curse.

lg.head: LXXVIII.
lg.l: Stand forth! and save these happy lands,
Ere 'tis, alas! too late;
Oppose all lawless mad commands,
Tremble at Boston's fate.

lg.head: LXXIX.
lg.l: Arise! shake off the Congress yoke;
Act as Freemen becomes.
Their book is bluster all, and smoke,
Ah! wipe with it your b—s.

lg.head: LXXX.
lg.l: If blind, you'll bow your humble pates,
Like moles, and deaf as stone,
To their High Mightiness' mandates,
I shall your fate bemoan.

lg.head: LXXXI
lg.l: And weeping pray, on reverent knees,
That God will pleased be,
To burn the Congresses decrees,
And blast their tyranny.

lg.head: LXXXII.
lg.l: But, Oh! God bless our honest King,
The Lords and Commons true.
And if next Congress is the thing,
Oh! bless that Congress too.
